Award.AwardTitle: SFS Scholarship Track: HOLISTiC - Human & Organizational Learning - Integrated STudies in Cybersecurity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As the cyber threat continues to grow at an exponential pace, the US is challenged to find cybersecurity leaders who are equipped with technical cybersecurity knowledge and an understanding of the organizational phenomena that impact the successful implementation of cybersecurity initiatives. The HOLISTiC (Human & Organizational Learning - Integrated STudies in Cybersecurity) program is meeting this challenge by piloting a doctoral-level Cybercorps program to develop cybersecurity leaders who are able to effectively navigate the complex and unpredictable cybersecurity environment.

HOLISTiC is being implemented within the George Washington University (GW) Executive Leadership Doctoral Program (ELP) in Human and Organizational Learning (HOL). Working closely with the ELP program faculty and advisors, and through the integration of dissertation research from program entry, students are working toward the completion of doctoral degree requirements in 3 years. The HOLISTiC program is producing 6 cybersecurity leaders who have a strong technical foundation and expertise in key areas such as risk analysis, information management, and organizational change; a portfolio of advanced research and analysis skills; establishing a community of practice that engages students and cybersecurity experts in collective dialogue, and; driving the development of practically-based, rigorous research on cybersecurity challenges that span technical and non-technical areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the HOLISTiC Executive CyberCorps Program was to transform cybersecurity technical experts into executive-level managers. The HOLISTiC program was launched to explore three general hypotheses: whether cybersecurity technical experts would benefit from executive leadership education, if the Cyber Corps structure could be applied to doctoral level education, and whether material benefits to the cybersecurity community could be achieved through this effort.

The findings from the HOLISTiC experiment address both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the program and are summarized as follows:

  1. Collective learning in advanced human and organizational theory is a powerful approach for senior personnel to expand their individual capabilities;
  2. Teaching “soft” sciences to cybersecurity professionals can make them more effective in executing “hard” science solutions;
  3. Teaching research methods and approaches enriches the knowledge bases of cybersecurity leaders; and
  4. There is significant and value in the basic concept of taking highly technical individuals and teaching them how to respond to the human factors skills of executive leadership which directly impact how this technology is used.

The HOLISTiC Executive CyberCorps Program was designed to create a specialized doctoral level learning environment in which existing cybersecurity technical experts could explore the meaning of leadership, learn the fundamentals of human and organizational learning, and pursue research in contemporary challenges for cybersecurity’s executive leaders.  In June 2014, six students were accepted into the pilot program. Two students withdrew from the program before completing coursework; one student relocated due to a job change and the second student withdrew due to a significant medical diagnosis. Of the four students remaining at the end of the project period, one student had successfully completed the doctoral program and three students were actively working toward completion of their dissertation research.

The executive-style program allowed students to simultaneously study as full-time students and work full-time in career positions. As they developed their skillsets, the “cyberdoc” cohort members met to explore the human and organizational aspects of technical cybersecurity concepts and to present their scholarly work at conferences and technical meetings. 

Together, the cyberdocs developed in a strong community of scholar-practitioners. While students expressed initial hesitation to presenting at academic conferences, those same students acknowledged afterward that the professional development requirement was enormously valuable in cementing their internalized understanding of how to communicate their cybersecurity knowledge to diverse audiences. One student recommended that executive coaching would be an excellent addition to the program.  Another student suggested that having more interaction with senior leaders would be a useful addition for possible future cohorts.

Throughout the pilot program period, the PIs collected student feedback to gain summative and cumulative programmatic insight.  The students express strong program support, referring to it as “transformative” and “eye opening”. While the full impact of their studies will not be known for several years, it does appear at this point that the program is in fact achieving its objectives to create holistic cybersecurity executive leaders. Further, conversations with each reveal that their appreciation for the executive challenges associated with cybersecurity has advanced to a sophisticated level that is changing both the manner in which they execute their current positions as well as how they anticipate and engage with the future needs of the cybersecurity ecosystem. The students pointed out that they were established leaders in their fields, had developed their own leadership styles based on their professional backgrounds, and yet were amazed at how much they were learning about leadership in the classes.  The following quote captures overall student sentiment: 

“The technology is easy, that’s not where the problem is, the problem is in the policies, the procedures the organizational culture” … “What I’d like to see is the mindset transition from being very technically focused and solving the challenge which is my opinion is just a band aid, right? To having a more holistic view of cyber security starting with the organizational science aspect of it, right? I think that’s where the answer lies but unfortunately a lot of our executives don’t have that knowledge or that training, right? So they end up focusing on the easy part, which is finding the next gismo or gadget.”

The most significant critique of the HOLISTiC program that has not yet been addressed was regarding its marketability. While all students repeatedly emphasized how valuable this program has already proven to be, they felt that on first glance, professionals may not comprehend the importance and rarity of this doctorate because the name was not self-explanatory. One student posited that if the name of the program was changed to “Doctorate in Cybersecurity Leadership,” the demand would be overwhelming.  

In sum, it seems clear that the general approach is very sound and that the program should be able to be replicated widely.
